title: Independence vs. Togetherness
description: Explore how you balance financial autonomy with partnership.

questions.text: When it comes to managing money, I believe couples should...
choices: Merge everything—what's mine is ours
Keep things mostly separate with some shared
Have a shared pool for joint expenses, rest separate
Figure out what works for their unique situation

therapeutic.rationale: Money merging preferences reveal values about autonomy, trust, and partnership. Full-mergers prioritize unity; separators prioritize independence; hybrid approachers balance both. There's no right answer—only alignment.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different merging preferences can feel threatening. The merger may feel the separator doesn't trust; the separator may feel the merger is controlling. Both can be expressions of love.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared merging philosophy makes designing your system easier. You agree on the basic structure.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What does money merging (or not) represent to you? What would it mean about your relationship?

choices: Important for my sense of independence
Nice but not essential
Unnecessary if we're truly partners
Complicated—I have mixed feelings

therapeutic.rationale: Personal money represents autonomy and identity for some, and separateness for others. Independence-needers require their own funds; partnership-focusers see separation as distance. Feelings here are deeply personal.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The independence-needer may feel controlled without personal money; the partnership-focuser may feel shut out by it. Understand the meaning behind the preference.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared feelings about personal money make this easier to navigate. You understand each other's needs.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you feel about having (or not having) money that's just yours? Where does that feeling come from?

questions.text: Before spending on something just for me, I feel like I should...
choices: Check in with my partner first
Use my own discretionary money freely
Consider whether it affects us, then decide
It depends on how much it costs

therapeutic.rationale: Personal spending autonomy reflects boundaries and trust. Check-in-firsters prioritize partnership; free-spenders prioritize autonomy; considerers balance; cost-dependers have thresholds. Expectations here often go unspoken.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different autonomy expectations can create friction. The check-inner may feel the free-spender is selfish; the free-spender may feel the check-inner is controlling. Agree on boundaries explicitly.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared autonomy expectations prevent a common conflict. You naturally agree on how personal spending works.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How would you feel if your partner spent money without telling you? What if they wanted you to check in about everything?

questions.text: Financial decisions that affect both of us should be...
choices: Made together, always
Made together for big things, solo for small
Discussed but one person can decide
Trusted to whoever handles that area

therapeutic.rationale: Joint decision-making style reveals power dynamics and trust. Always-togethers maximize input; threshold-setters are practical; discussers trust judgment; delegators specialize. Misalignment creates power struggles.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The always-together person may feel shut out by delegation; the delegator may feel micromanaged by joint decisions. Find the balance that honors both needs.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared decision-making style makes financial choices smoother. You agree on how decisions get made.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you feel when decisions are made without your input? What level of involvement feels right?

questions.text: The balance I want between financial independence and togetherness is...
choices: Mostly togetherness with some personal freedom
Mostly independence with clear shared responsibilities
Equal balance—both matter a lot to me
Flexible depending on the season of life

therapeutic.rationale: The independence-togetherness balance is deeply personal and often unspoken. Naming your ideal helps your partner understand what you need and helps you design a system that works.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different balances require negotiation. The togetherness-leaner may feel the independence-leaner is distant; the independence-leaner may feel the togetherness-leaner is enmeshed. Both needs are valid.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared balance makes designing your financial life easier. You're aiming for the same structure.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What does financial partnership mean to you? What does financial independence mean? How do you want to balance them?
